taskbody.context: This procedure configures an NTP master server on the master nodes. If you have an NTP time server inside your firewall, you may configure the master nodes to use it; however, this procedure does not include that option.
Perform this procedure on the primary node and on the secondary node.

step.cmd: Create a backup of the NTP configuration file.

substep.cmd: Replace all of the lines in the file with the following lines:

stepxmp.codeblock:
# Use the local clock server 127.127.1.0 prefer fudge 127.127.1.0 stratum 10 driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift broadcastdelay 0.008
# Give localhost full access rights restrict 127.0.0.1
# Grant access to client hosts restrict Address-Range mask Netmask nomodify notrap

substep.cmd: Replace Address-Range with the range of IPv4 network addresses that are allowed to query this NTP server.

stepxmp.p: For example, the following IP addresses are assigned to the hosts in a cluster: 203.0.113.10 203.0.113.11 203.0.113.12 203.0.113.13
For the preceding addresses, the value for Address-Range is 203.0.113.0.

substep.cmd: Replace Netmask with the IPv4 network mask that corresponds with the address range.
substep.stepxmp: For example, the network mask for 203.0.113.0 is 255.255.255.0.

substep.cmd: Save the file and exit the editor.

step.cmd: Enable and start the NTP daemon.

substep.cmd: Configure ntpd to start when the system starts.
substep.info: Currently, an unresolved issue associated with NTP prevents ntpd from restarting correctly after a reboot, and the following commands provide a workaround to ensure that it does.
